trans-unit.source: The <xref href="System.Data.SqlClient.SqlDependency"></xref> object represents a query notification dependency between an application and an instance of SQL Server.

An application can create a <xref href="System.Data.SqlClient.SqlDependency"></xref> object and register to receive notifications via the <xref href="System.Data.SqlClient.OnChangeEventHandler"></xref> event handler.
<xref:System.Data.SqlClient.SqlDependency> is ideal for caching scenarios, where your ASP.NET application or middle-tier service needs to keep certain information cached in memory.
<xref:System.Data.SqlClient.SqlDependency> allows you to receive notifications when the original data in the database changes so that the cache can be refreshed.
To set up a dependency, you need to associate a <xref:System.Data.SqlClient.SqlDependency> object to one or more <xref:System.Data.SqlClient.SqlCommand> objects.
To receive notifications, you need to subscribe to the <xref:System.Data.SqlClient.SqlDependency.OnChange> event.
For more information about the requirements for creating queries for notifications, see "Creating a Query for Notification" in SQL Server Books Online.

<xref:System.Data.SqlClient.SqlDependency> was designed to be used in ASP.NET or middle-tier services where there is a relatively small number of servers having dependencies active against the database.
It was not designed for use in client applications, where hundreds or thousands of client computers would have <xref:System.Data.SqlClient.SqlDependency> objects set up for a single database server.

If you are developing an application where you need reliable sub-second notifications when data changes, review the sections **Planning an Efficient Query Notifications Strategy** and **Alternatives to Query Notifications** in the [Planning for Notifications](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=211984) topic in SQL Server Books Online.
For more information, see [Query Notifications in SQL Server](~/docs/framework/data/adonet/sql/query-notifications-in-sql-server.md) and "Building Notification Solutions" in SQL Server Books Online.
The <xref:System.Data.SqlClient.SqlDependency.OnChange> event may be generated on a different thread from the thread that initiated command execution.
Query notifications are supported only for SELECT statements that meet a list of specific requirements.
The following table provides links to the Service Broker and Query Notifications documentation in SQL Server Books Online.

Creates a new instance of the <xref href="System.Data.SqlClient.SqlDependency"></xref> class with the default settings.
The constructor initializes the <xref:System.Data.SqlClient.SqlDependency> object using the default Service Broker service name and time-out.

At some point after construction, you must use the <xref:System.Data.SqlClient.SqlDependency.AddCommandDependency%2A> method to associate one or more commands to this <xref:System.Data.SqlClient.SqlDependency> object.
Query notifications are supported only for SELECT statements that meet a list of specific requirements.

Creates a new instance of the <xref href="System.Data.SqlClient.SqlDependency"></xref> class and associates it with the <xref href="System.Data.SqlClient.SqlCommand"></xref> parameter.
Internally, this constructor creates an instance of the <xref:System.Data.Sql.SqlNotificationRequest> class, and binds it to a <xref:System.Data.SqlClient.SqlCommand> object.
Query notifications are supported only for SELECT statements that meet a list of specific requirements.
The following table provides links to the Service Broker and Query Notifications documentation in SQL Server Books Online.
**SQL Server Books Online**
[Creating a Query for Notification](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/ms181122.aspx)
[Security Considerations for Service Broker](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/ms166059.aspx)

[Security Considerations for Notifications Services](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/ms172604.aspx)
[Query Notification Permissions](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/ms188311.aspx)
[International Considerations for Service Broker](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/ms166028.aspx)
[Solution Design Considerations (Service Broker)](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/bb522899.aspx)
[Service Broker Developer InfoCenter](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/ms166100.aspx)
[Developer's Guide (Service Broker)](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/bb522908.aspx)
The <xref href="System.Data.SqlClient.SqlCommand"></xref> object to associate with this <xref href="System.Data.SqlClient.SqlDependency"></xref> object.
The constructor will set up a <xref href="System.Data.Sql.SqlNotificationRequest"></xref> object and bind it to the command.
The command parameter is NULL.

The <xref href="System.Data.SqlClient.SqlCommand"></xref> object already has a <xref href="System.Data.Sql.SqlNotificationRequest"></xref> object assigned to its <xref href="System.Data.SqlClient.SqlCommand.Notification"></xref> property, and that <xref href="System.Data.Sql.SqlNotificationRequest"></xref> is not associated with this dependency.

Creates a new instance of the <xref href="System.Data.SqlClient.SqlDependency"></xref> class, associates it with the <xref href="System.Data.SqlClient.SqlCommand"></xref> parameter, and specifies notification options and a time-out value.
Query notifications are supported only for SELECT statements that meet a list of specific requirements.
The following table provides links to the Service Broker and Query Notifications documentation in SQL Server Books Online.

[Solution Design Considerations (Service Broker)](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/bb522899.aspx)
[Service Broker Developer InfoCenter](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/ms166100.aspx)
[Developer's Guide (Service Broker)](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/bb522908.aspx)
The <xref href="System.Data.SqlClient.SqlCommand"></xref> object to associate with this <xref href="System.Data.SqlClient.SqlDependency"></xref> object.
The constructor sets up a <xref href="System.Data.Sql.SqlNotificationRequest"></xref> object and bind it to the command.
The notification request options to be used by this dependency.
null to use the default service.
The time-out for this notification in seconds.
The default is 0, indicating that the server's time-out should be used.
The command parameter is NULL.
The time-out value is less than zero.

The <xref href="System.Data.SqlClient.SqlCommand"></xref> object already has a <xref href="System.Data.Sql.SqlNotificationRequest"></xref> object assigned to its <xref href="System.Data.SqlClient.SqlCommand.Notification"></xref> property and that <xref href="System.Data.Sql.SqlNotificationRequest"></xref> is not associated with this dependency.
An attempt was made to create a **SqlDependency** instance from within SQLCLR.
Associates a <xref href="System.Data.SqlClient.SqlCommand"></xref> object with this <xref href="System.Data.SqlClient.SqlDependency"></xref> instance.
Query notifications are supported only for SELECT statements that meet a list of specific requirements.
The following table provides links to the Service Broker and Query Notifications documentation in SQL Server Books Online.
**SQL Server Books Online**
[Creating a Query for Notification](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/ms181122.aspx)
[Security Considerations for Service Broker](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/ms166059.aspx)
[Security and Protection (Service Broker)](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/bb522911.aspx)
[Security Considerations for Notifications Services](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/ms172604.aspx)
[Query Notification Permissions](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/ms188311.aspx)
[International Considerations for Service Broker](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/ms166028.aspx)
[Solution Design Considerations (Service Broker)](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/bb522899.aspx)
[Service Broker Developer InfoCenter](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/ms166100.aspx)
[Developer's Guide (Service Broker)](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/bb522908.aspx)
A <xref href="System.Data.SqlClient.SqlCommand"></xref> object containing a statement that is valid for notifications.
The command parameter is null.

The <xref href="System.Data.SqlClient.SqlCommand"></xref> object already has a <xref href="System.Data.Sql.SqlNotificationRequest"></xref> object assigned to its <xref href="System.Data.SqlClient.SqlCommand.Notification"></xref> property, and that <xref href="System.Data.Sql.SqlNotificationRequest"></xref> is not associated with this dependency.
Gets a value that indicates whether one of the result sets associated with the dependency has changed.

If you are not using the <xref:System.Data.SqlClient.SqlDependency.OnChange> event, you can check the <xref:System.Data.SqlClient.SqlDependency.HasChanges%2A> property to determine if the query results have changed.
The <xref:System.Data.SqlClient.SqlDependency.HasChanges%2A> property does not necessarily imply a change in the data.
Other circumstances, such as time-out expired and failure to set the notification request, also generate a change event.
A Boolean value indicating whether one of the result sets has changed.
Gets a value that uniquely identifies this instance of the <xref href="System.Data.SqlClient.SqlDependency"></xref> class.
The <xref:System.Data.SqlClient.SqlDependency.Id%2A> property is used to uniquely identify a given <xref:System.Data.SqlClient.SqlDependency> instance.
A string representation of a GUID that is generated for each instance of the <xref href="System.Data.SqlClient.SqlDependency"></xref> class.
Occurs when a notification is received for any of the commands associated with this <xref href="System.Data.SqlClient.SqlDependency"></xref> object.
<xref:System.Data.SqlClient.SqlDependency.OnChange> occurs when the results for the associated command change.

If you are not using <xref:System.Data.SqlClient.SqlDependency.OnChange>, you can check the <xref:System.Data.SqlClient.SqlDependency.HasChanges%2A> property to determine whether the query results have changed.
The <xref:System.Data.SqlClient.SqlDependency.OnChange> event does not necessarily imply a change in the data.
Other circumstances, such as time-out expired and failure to set the notification request, also generate <xref:System.Data.SqlClient.SqlDependency.OnChange>.
Starts the listener for receiving dependency change notifications from the instance of SQL Server specified by the connection string.

This method starts the listener for the <xref:System.AppDomain> for receiving dependency notifications from the instance of [!INCLUDE[ssNoVersion](~/includes/ssnoversion-md.md)] specified by the `connectionString` parameter.
This method may be called more than once with different connection strings for multiple servers.
For additional remarks, see <xref:System.Data.SqlClient.SqlDependency.Start%2A>.
The connection string for the instance of [!INCLUDE[ssNoVersion](~/includes/ssnoversion-md.md)] from which to obtain change notifications.
**true** if the listener initialized successfully; **false** if a compatible listener already exists.
The connectionString parameter is NULL.
The connectionString parameter is the same as a previous call to this method, but the parameters are different.
The method was called from within the CLR.
The caller does not have the required <xref href="System.Data.SqlClient.SqlClientPermission"></xref> code access security (CAS) permission.
A subsequent call to the method has been made with an equivalent connectionString parameter with a different user, or a user that does not default to the same schema.
Also, any underlying **SqlClient** exceptions.
Starts the listener for receiving dependency change notifications from the instance of SQL Server specified by the connection string using the specified SQL Server Service Broker queue.
This method starts the listener for the <xref:System.AppDomain> for receiving dependency notifications from the instance of SQL Server specified by the `connectionString` parameter.
This method may be called more than once with different connection strings for multiple servers.

If no queue name is specified, <xref:System.Data.SqlClient.SqlDependency> creates a temporary queue and service in the server that is used for the entire process, even if the process involves more than one <xref:System.AppDomain>.
The queue and service are automatically removed upon application shutdown.
For additional remarks, see <xref:System.Data.SqlClient.SqlDependency.Start%2A>.
The connection string for the instance of SQL Server from which to obtain change notifications.
An existing SQL Server Service Broker queue to be used.
If `null`, the default queue is used.
**true** if the listener initialized successfully; **false** if a compatible listener already exists.
The connectionString parameter is NULL.
The connectionString parameter is the same as a previous call to this method, but the parameters are different.
The method was called from within the CLR.
The caller does not have the required <xref href="System.Data.SqlClient.SqlClientPermission"></xref> code access security (CAS) permission.
A subsequent call to the method has been made with an equivalent connectionString parameter but a different user, or a user that does not default to the same schema.
Also, any underlying **SqlClient** exceptions.
Stops a listener for a connection specified in a previous <xref href="System.Data.SqlClient.SqlDependency.Start*"></xref> call.
The <xref:System.Data.SqlClient.SqlDependency.Stop%2A> method must be called for each <xref:System.Data.SqlClient.SqlDependency.Start%2A> call.
A given listener only shuts down fully when it receives the same number of <xref:System.Data.SqlClient.SqlDependency.Stop%2A> requests as <xref:System.Data.SqlClient.SqlDependency.Start%2A> requests.
Connection string for the instance of SQL Server that was used in a previous <xref href="System.Data.SqlClient.SqlDependency.Start(System.String)"></xref> call.

**true** if the listener was completely stopped; **false** if the <xref href="System.AppDomain"></xref> was unbound from the listener, but there are is at least one other <xref href="System.AppDomain"></xref> using the same listener.
The connectionString parameter is NULL.
The method was called from within SQLCLR.
The caller does not have the required <xref href="System.Data.SqlClient.SqlClientPermission"></xref> code access security (CAS) permission.
An underlying **SqlClient** exception occurred.
Stops a listener for a connection specified in a previous <xref href="System.Data.SqlClient.SqlDependency.Start*"></xref> call.
The <xref:System.Data.SqlClient.SqlDependency.Stop%2A> method must be called for each <xref:System.Data.SqlClient.SqlDependency.Start%2A> call.
A given listener only shuts down fully when it receives the same number of <xref:System.Data.SqlClient.SqlDependency.Stop%2A> requests as <xref:System.Data.SqlClient.SqlDependency.Start%2A> requests.
Connection string for the instance of SQL Server that was used in a previous <xref href="System.Data.SqlClient.SqlDependency.Start(System.String,System.String)"></xref> call.
The SQL Server Service Broker queue that was used in a previous <xref href="System.Data.SqlClient.SqlDependency.Start(System.String,System.String)"></xref> call.

**true** if the listener was completely stopped; **false** if the <xref href="System.AppDomain"></xref> was unbound from the listener, but there is at least one other <xref href="System.AppDomain"></xref> using the same listener.
The connectionString parameter is NULL.
The method was called from within SQLCLR.
The caller does not have the required <xref href="System.Data.SqlClient.SqlClientPermission"></xref> code access security (CAS) permission.
And underlying **SqlClient** exception occurred.
